content.description: Twin cracks at the start that will lead you to an offwidth. Large ledges and jugs will follow after the offwidth.
content.protection: Fence posts at the summit for TR anchors.
content.location: To the left of Right Crack

content.description: Chimney climb with few solid foot holds. It's fairly difficult to smear so be prepared to use your upper body.
content.protection: The fence posts at the summit can be used as top rope anchors.
content.location: The route is just to the right of the Right Crack.

content.description: Twin cracks at the start. The crux is 3/4 of the way up.
content.protection: Fence posts are at the summit and they can be used as anchors.

content.description: Twin cracks at the start are available for solid toe jams and fingers. There is a rose bush growing in a crack half way up the route. Be aware of this so you don't grab onto it and get a fistful of thorns. This route may have been the first toprope ever done in North Dakota back in 1994.
content.protection: Fence posts at the summit for TR anchors.
content.location: Left-hand side of the butte near the center.

content.description: Somewhat easy route route that moves right. Some loose rock up top. Rock is pretty soft and I suspect cams would likely rip out.
content.protection: Two fence posts on top for anchors
content.location: It is to the right of the obvious corner on the left side of the formation. Just look at the picture.

content.description: For the lost, stranded, or otherwise misplaced ones of the Bakken oil fields, this is a small sanctuary.  It's on public grasslands, but the land is also leased by nearby ranchers. Please be mindful of this. The rock is a very poor quality siltstone, and large boulders and flakes can detach easily. Some care has been given to clean loose debris off several of these short pitches, but things can change. The T stakes were pounded in sometime during the spring of 2015, but accelerated corrosion is not uncommon in the vicinity of oil production sites.
